item.title: The power of incentives
item.description: In the 19th century, the British government faced a critical dilemma when it came to transporting prisoners to Australia. The prisoner survival rate was a worrying 40 per cent. In an effort to improve it, various government organizations and humanitarian groups proposed improvements. But after several attempts, the survival rate remained at 40 per cent. The situation did not improve until Edwin Chadwick, a visionary economist, decided to change the focus of the problem.
